title: Towards prevention of autoimmune diseases: the case of rheumatoid arthritis
abstract: A common feature of autoantibody-positive autoimmune disease is that the disease-associated autoimmunity often appears many years prior to clinical onset and can hence be used to identify risk groups for future disease development. Autoantibody-positive (seropositive) rheumatoid arthritis (RA) provides a unique setting due to recent insights in the longitudinal development of the disease, suggesting that autoantibodies develop in genetic susceptible individuals as a consequence of specific environmental challenges (such as smoking) to only later on target the joints. The main objectives of the current program are: (1). To dissect the longitudinal development of seropositive RA and gain a detailed understanding of the processes responsible for autoantibody generation outside the joints, and specifically at the mucosal sites. (2). To develop new ways to identify seropositive disease-susceptible individuals and map targetable life style factors and immune events responsible for this susceptibility. (3). To elucidate the mechanisms by which systemic autoimmunity targets the joints to first induce bone loss and pain and only in a second phase chronic joint inflammation.  If successful our project will not only allow efficient identification of RA-susceptible individuals, but also deliver new tools for risk estimation in each of these individuals and novel ways of intervention in order to delay, or in the best case prevent disease development. By shifting the time (to phases before joint damage and disability occurs) and the ways (to drugs targeting early previously unknown pathogenic mechanisms) of interventions, expected results from the current project are beyond the current state of the art in RA.

motivations: Autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, often exhibit autoimmunity years before clinical onset, providing an opportunity for early identification and prevention.
Current understanding of rheumatoid arthritis development is limited, hindering the development of effective prevention strategies.
objectives: Dissect the longitudinal development of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis to understand autoantibody generation outside the joints.
Identify seropositive disease-susceptible individuals and map targetable lifestyle factors and immune events contributing to susceptibility.
Elucidate the mechanisms by which systemic autoimmunity targets the joints to induce bone loss, pain, and chronic inflammation.
methods: Investigate the longitudinal development of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, focusing on mucosal sites and autoantibody generation.
Develop new methods to identify susceptible individuals and assess lifestyle factors and immune events contributing to disease susceptibility.
Examine the mechanisms of systemic autoimmunity targeting the joints and inducing disease progression.
results: Enable efficient identification of rheumatoid arthritis-susceptible individuals and provide new tools for risk estimation and intervention.
Deliver novel ways to delay or prevent disease development by targeting early pathogenic mechanisms.
Improve understanding of rheumatoid arthritis development, leading to interventions beyond the current state of the art.
llama_json.research_subject: Prevention of autoimmune diseases, specifically rheumatoid arthritis, through early identification and intervention

motivations: Autoantibody-positive autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), often exhibit disease-associated autoimmunity years before clinical onset, indicating a potential for early identification and prevention.
There is a need to understand the processes responsible for autoantibody generation outside the joints, particularly at mucosal sites, in seropositive RA.
Understanding how systemic autoimmunity targets the joints to induce bone loss, pain, and chronic joint inflammation could provide insights into disease prevention.
objectives: Dissect the longitudinal development of seropositive RA and understand the processes responsible for autoantibody generation outside the joints.
Develop new methods to identify seropositive disease-susceptible individuals and map targetable lifestyle factors and immune events responsible for this susceptibility.
Elucidate the mechanisms by which systemic autoimmunity targets the joints, leading to bone loss, pain, and chronic joint inflammation.
methods: Longitudinal study of the development of seropositive RA, focusing on autoantibody generation outside the joints.
Identification of seropositive disease-susceptible individuals and mapping of targetable lifestyle factors and immune events.
Investigation of the mechanisms by which systemic autoimmunity targets the joints.
results: Efficient identification of RA-susceptible individuals and new tools for risk estimation.
Novel ways of intervention to delay or prevent disease development.
Shifting the time and ways of interventions, with expected results beyond the current state of the art in RA.
openai_json.research_subject: Prevention of autoimmune diseases with a focus on rheumatoid arthritis

motivations: Autoantibody-positive autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis develop years before clinical symptoms appear, creating an opportunity for early intervention.
Current understanding of how autoimmunity develops outside the joints and subsequently targets them is limited, hindering effective prevention strategies.
objectives: Dissect the longitudinal development of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis and understand the processes responsible for autoantibody generation at mucosal sites.
Develop methods to identify disease-susceptible individuals and map targetable lifestyle factors and immune events responsible for susceptibility.
Elucidate the mechanisms by which systemic autoimmunity targets joints to induce bone loss, pain, and chronic inflammation.
methods: Investigate the longitudinal development of autoantibodies in genetically susceptible individuals exposed to environmental challenges.
Analyze the role of mucosal sites in autoantibody generation and the transition from systemic autoimmunity to joint-specific pathology.
Develop risk assessment tools and intervention strategies targeting early pathogenic mechanisms.
results: Enable efficient identification of rheumatoid arthritis-susceptible individuals with new tools for personalized risk estimation.
Develop novel intervention strategies to delay or prevent disease development before joint damage occurs.
Advance understanding of early pathogenic mechanisms to create targeted therapies beyond current treatment approaches.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Prevention of rheumatoid arthritis through understanding autoantibody development and early disease mechanisms
